Comments_List: Survey of primary and secondary literature on teleology and mechanism

I was exposed to a variety of philosophical literature that challenged my reasoning skills. I gained a broad understanding of teleological and mechanistic thought in the history of philosophy as well as philosophy of science.
Trajectory of key primary texts on the topic and focused secondary literature. Discussion during seminar was limited.

Paul Franks is a brilliant instructor, and our class discussions were always helpful for understanding the readings and evaluating their merits. We gained a bird's eye view of teleology and mechanism in history which is extremely valuable for seeing the trends, but that said, I would have liked to spend a little more time on each figure. I also would have liked to read more primary rather than secondary sources. But overall, it was a great class, and I think such an expansive topic required a more broad course outline.

This course covered several major figures in the history of philosophy. This was both its strength and its weakness. Its breadth was a strength, because I was introduced to a wide-range of texts and thoughts on the topic. At the same time, I found many of the texts difficult to navigate. In order to get a better grasp on the ideas, I suggest the class spend more time on fewer thinkers. I will say, however, that I found it helpful when Prof. Franks gave an introduction to the thinker the week before our assigned reading.  If the breadth is retained, I suggest continuing this method.
Yes both in terms of content and method.

Yes, as long as the student's interest line up relatively to this subject. It is a topic which is perhaps understudied yet taken for granted in much philosophical and scientific discourse. It touches on a lot of different topics and is important to understand in the broader contemporary academic world.
